goals.question: What is the trend of unemployment rate over the years?
goals.visualization: Line chart of unemployment rate against year
goals.rationale: This visualization helps to identify if there is a general increase or decrease in unemployment rate over the years.

goals.question: What is the distribution of unemployment rate across different states?
goals.visualization: Bar chart of unemployment rate against state
goals.rationale: This visualization helps to identify which states have higher or lower unemployment rates.

goals.question: What is the relationship between unemployment rate and education level?
goals.visualization: Scatter plot of unemployment rate against education level
goals.rationale: This visualization helps to identify if there is a correlation between education level and unemployment rate.

goals.question: What is the distribution of unemployment rate by gender?
goals.visualization: Stacked bar chart of unemployment rate against gender
goals.rationale: This visualization helps to identify if there is a difference in unemployment rate between genders.

goals.question: What is the trend of unemployment rate for different age groups?
goals.visualization: Line chart of unemployment rate against age group
goals.rationale: This visualization helps to identify if there is a difference in unemployment rate between age groups and if there is a trend over time.

code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['year'] = pd.to_datetime(data['year'], errors='coerce')
    data = data[pd.notna(data['year'])]
    data['year'] = data['year'].dt.year

    plt.plot(data['year'], data['unemployment_rate'], label='Unemployment Rate')
    plt.xlabel('Year')
    plt.ylabel('Unemployment Rate')
    plt.title('What is the trend of unemployment rate over the years?', wrap=True)
    plt.legend()
    plt.xticks(rotation=45)
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data = data.sort_values(by='unemployment_rate', ascending=False)
    plt.figure(figsize=(15, 6))
    plt.bar(data['state'], data['unemployment_rate'], color='b')
    plt.xlabel('State')
    plt.ylabel('Unemployment Rate')
    plt.xticks(rotation=90)
    plt.title('What is the distribution of unemployment rate across different states?', wrap=True)
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    plt.scatter(data['education_level'], data['unemployment_rate'])
    plt.xlabel('Education Level')
    plt.ylabel('Unemployment Rate')
    plt.title('What is the relationship between unemployment rate and education level?', wrap=True)
    plt.xticks(rotation=45)
    plt.legend(['Unemployment Rate'])
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    # Group data by gender and calculate the mean unemployment rate for each gender
    gender_unemployment = data.groupby('gender')['unemployment_rate'].mean()

    # Create a stacked bar chart
    ax = gender_unemployment.plot(kind='bar', stacked=True)

    # Set the title and labels
    plt.title('What is the distribution of unemployment rate by gender?', wrap=True)
    plt.xlabel('Gender')
    plt.ylabel('Unemployment Rate')

    # Add a legend
    ax.legend(["Unemployment Rate"])

    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['date'] = pd.to_datetime(data['date'], errors='coerce')
    data = data[pd.notna(data['date'])]
    
    age_groups = data['age_group'].unique()
    for age_group in age_groups:
        age_data = data[data['age_group'] == age_group]
        plt.plot(age_data['date'], age_data['unemployment_rate'], label=age_group)
    
    plt.xlabel('Date')
    plt.ylabel('Unemployment Rate')
    plt.title('What is the trend of unemployment rate for different age groups?', wrap=True)
    plt.legend(title='Age Group')
    plt.xticks(rotation=45)
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)
